newsitem.title: USA: GenRad sees 1996 EPS of at least $1.00.
newsitem.headline: GenRad sees 1996 EPS of at least $1.00.

text.p: GenRad Inc chief executive officer James Lyons told analysts in a conference call Wednesday he expected to keep his promise to shareholders of earnings per share of "$1.00 a share or more" in 1996.

"We have come a long way from the fall of 1993," when the Concord, Mass.,-based company, was losing money, Lyons said. "We will earn $1.00 a share or more in 1996...Our net worth has turned positive to the tune of $336,000."
GenRad, which acquired Mitron Corp, Test Technology Associates and Field Oriented Engineering AG (TRACS) in 1996, expects to continue making acquisitions, Lyons said.

Genrad's vice president of strategic planning, Sarah Lucas, said, "We are actively, agressively looking for acquisitions." Lyons said he expected the acquisitions would be in the "transaction range of $3 million to $4 million to $5 million.
"Most of these transactions will be whenever possible pooling, using stock. Some will be for cash," Lyons said. "There will be little, if any, dilution to speak of."
Lyons estimated that earnings per share in 1997 would be no less than $1.25 per share.
First Call said it had only two analysts' projections for GenRad in 1996 with a consensus of $0.88 a share. Its single projection for 1997 EPS was $1.15.

Lyons said with the positive net worth -- the first time since 1991 GenRad has been in that position -- "We have concluded the financial turnaround" and now GenRad is in the midst of a strategic turnaround.

GenRad, which has 1,150 employees world wide, provides software, systems and services to makers of electronic products. It has seen a shift in its major customers to telecommunications and contract manufacturers during 1996.
Lyons said International Business Machines Corp has replaced the U.S. Marine Corp as GenRad's third largest customer.
